You can find lot of pictures and a rule discussion forum on their German webpage: www.history-of-war.com [you can change the webpage language clicking on the UK banner on the left, once in]
8134.name: History of War

8136.description: This is a childrens motorized action game. There were 4 different games each packaged separately possessing a different theme. This is the medieval themed game Sir Ring-A-Lot. Collectively, the games were called T.H.I.N.G.S. or Totally Hillarious Incredibly Neat Games of Skill. Ages 5 and up for 1 or more players. Basically, you push on the tower which pushes the knight up allowing the player to "spear" the rings that are picked up by the flying bats rotating around the castle. From the box: "Capture the Rings from the Fly-By-Knight Bats!"
8136.name: Sir Ring-A-Lot

8137.name: Spacefarers
8137.description:
A very early offering from Games Workshop, and apparently an ancestor of what would become Warhammer 40,000, Spacefarers is "a set of science fiction skirmish rules designed specifically for the Spacefarers range of figures manufactured by Citadel Miniatures Ltd... The rules have been designed for two players to carry out small scale skirmishes with each player in control of a unit of Imperial Marines, Dark Disciples, Star Patrolmen, or independent gangs."

Most of the rules are pretty standard tabletop miniature skirmish rules. Each unit may move a certain number of inches per turn, may fire a ranged weapon, and/or engage in close combat with models in close proximity. No grid is used for movement, a ruler is used to measure linear distances.

Unlike the massive armies sported by the game's descendants, Spacefarers focuses on single squads, and allows for more detail, such as rudimentary hit location, along with different armor protection for each location, and individually equipped models. The game appears to have much more in common with games like Necromunda or Mordheim in this respect.

The rules are short, only 44 pages, with sparse hand-drawn artwork; not a single photograph is used. Two introductory scenarios are included, rules are included for constructing your own forces. Depending on which force you choose to represent, you get a certain amount of "money" to use to buy equipment, and the rules indicate how large your squad will be (in one case, it's random!).

8138.description:
In the old days - not as good as usually reported - many dangers awaited a merchant. In addition to thieves, malcontented customers and too high tolls, trade routes weren't as secure as they are today. Storms, pirates, war, malevolent officials, silted-up harbors and other disasters afflicted the trade routes.

And so it could happen that cities which yesterday were only a few days away now lay at opposite corners of the known world. Precisely these problems are depicted in the game of Kogge.

Kogge is a game for two to four players. Across the web of trade routes, the players try to trade goods and to establish trade houses.

The ever-changing routes between cities don't make life easier for the merchants playing their trade on the Baltic Sea.
8138.name: Kogge

8139.description:
Take command of the Legions of Middle-earth with the LoTR: TMG.

Destroy the One Ring or claim its terrible power for your own in this fast paced game that uses expertly pre-painted miniatures, and the intuitive Combat Hex rules system to deliver the excitement of the Lord of the Rings movies right out of the box.

A brief rundown on how the game plays:
There are 4 phases in every turn.

Each turn starts with the Strategy phase, where players roll to determine who is the attacker and who is the defender for that turn. The player that rolls the highest can choose to be either.

The next phase is the attacker’s Action phase. In this phase, each of the attacker’s warriors can take one action. A warrior can move, shoot or do nothing as its action. Once the attacker is finished with all of his or her actions, the defender now gets their action phase.

The final phase is the Combat phase. This is when your warriors fight. Warriors killed in this phase aren’t removed until the very end, so they will at least get to fight back if they are struck down.
8139.name: The Lord of the Rings: Combat Hex Tradeable Miniatures Game

8140.name: Global Powers
8140.description:
From Terminal City Gamers webpage:

In May, the game was still presented as ‘Divide et Impera’. After much playtesting and more changes, the game has been renamed as Global Powers (2-5 players 14 and up). The object of the game is to exert the most influence over the world, which in this game consists of 12 regions.

“It’s a not-quite-politically-correct game with tactics, AGITATION and plenty of interaction” says publishing head Peter Eggert. “In order to obtain the necessary influence, players can use military, political or financial force. The player who has the most playing figures (politicians) in a given region determines which actions may be carried out there. The more politicians, the more actions. These range from waging war through sabotage, smuggling, scandal and defection to unrest and even a Putsch. Each action can be countered either by a veto or by being voted down. UN resolutions (administered by the players) can also influence the gameplay.”

8141.name: Countdown
8141.description:
Countdown is a mathematics educational game centered around the theme of sending a rocket into outer space.

Players roll dice and draw cards based on the dice's results. Even cards carry addition and multiplication problems that when answered correctly, move the answering player's token forward on the track (which is patterned like our solar system). Odd cards have subtraction and division questions; answering them correctly moves the player's token backwards. When a token lands on certain spaces with instructions, the player must carry out what was printed as well (lose a turn, move the token to another space, etc).

The game ends when a player's token reaches Pluto, making him or her the winner.

8142.name: The Family Game
8142.description: Family members gather to play. A playing deck is arranged from the question cards provided to reflect the relationships of the players. The players advance along the gameboard track by giving answers without being challenged as fakes. The first to reach the end of the track wins.

8143.description:
A children's game in which players advance around a circular track, partly by roll-and-move, but mainly by being able to recall four characteristics of a thief whose appearance constantly changes and who can only be glimpsed fleetingly as he is rotated between screens by a clockwork mechanism.

The first player to reach the end of the track is deemed to have arrested the thief and so won the game.
8143.name: Hook the Crook

8144.name: Combat
8144.description:
An introductory wargame, noteworthy for having been endorsed by one of the leading British generals of World War II.

The board consists of a plain grid of green squares. Terrain features are printed on vinyl that may be temporarily attached to the board creating a unique battlefield for each game.

There are three types of unit. Tanks move more quickly, while Guns can fire over a longer range. Aircraft can attack targets anywhere on the battlefield, but risk being shot down each time they do so.

The winner is the first player to achieve a 3:1 superiority in remaining units.

8145.name: Terminator 2: Judgment Day
8145.description:
Race to collect Terminator parts (arm and chip) and computer files, and then be the player to destroy the T-1000 cyborg.

First,you must run a frantic race around the board to find three high-tech equipment tokens.
As you rush to complete your mission, you must fight the dreaded T-1000, an incredible liquid-metal cyborg from the future. A roll of the battle dice will determine your success. Be the first to melt the T-1000 in a vat of molten steel and win the game!

Contents of British edition:
1 Game Board.
4 John/Sarah Conner Playing Pieces.
1 T-1000 Piece.
5 Stands.
12 High-Tech Equipment Tokens.
48 Cards.
3 Dice.
1 Rules Booklet.

8146.description: A pursuit type game similar to Candyland for little boys produced in 1963. Game was released with 3 other children's games by the publisher in the hopes of volumes of sales and profit in the children's game market in an eleventh hour effort to stave off bankruptcy. The 4 games released were not good sellers and in late 1963 the company went bankrupt, only to reappear in 1964 under new management and the company prospered in the market. Game uses a wooden die with faces of six different colors, a roll of the die shows the color space that the moving player advances to. Some spaces call for a return to the beginning or a move backward. The first player to the end of the track wins. The board is marked with the themes of transportation by, well, trucks, trains, boats and planes! The youngest player moves first, and the game can be played solitaire where the player tries to move the length of the track within an alloted number of rolls of the die. Game stock number was 101 and original 1963 price was $.98 A similar pursuit game for little girls was called The Doll House game, and the two other 1963 children's titles were Imagination and What Time Is It?
8146.name: Trucks, Trains, Boats and Planes game

8147.description:
The goal of the game is to bring your huts for the tourist hordes down on the beautiful island Maka Bana. Therefore you have 11 cards with terrain (4), a symbol (4), and the name of the beach (3). Each space on the board can be identified with this combination of three cards. These are played one face up & two face down. The aim is to get the most points. You get 1 point for a stand-alone-hut. You get more if you have huts on adjacent spaces. You have one TIKI (statue) to bring your opponents into trouble. You can put this one on any space you want. If your opponent wants to build there a hut: Bad Luck. There are also two cards which you use to change the color of a hut (to make it yours).
The game ends if one player managed it to place all his huts on the island or if one beach is complete with huts and/or tikis at the end of a turn.

In the advanced rules, it is possible to legally "cheat". If you play more than three cards, you can build more huts. If you play less than three cards, you can build more easily — but to prevent some excess, there can be only one denunciation every turn, and you can only denounce another player if you cheat "less" than your opponent!
8147.name: Maka Bana

8148.name: Trio
8148.description: Similar to Mag-Nif 's Rex but played on a staggered 3-2-3 square rather than on a triangle, this is a game of alignment constrained by the previously played pieces. Either player stacks pieces on long pegs, hoping to achieve as many lines vertically, horizontally or diagonally as possible --in three dimensions. All 24 pieces are played, then the alignments are counted: whoever achieved the most wins. Solitaire rules are also included.

8149.description:
Confrontation is a wargame covering hypothetical conflicts during the 1950-70 period on a global scale. It is fairly abstract, with generic land units but some detail on the capabilities of different air and naval units.

Confrontation was the first wargame to have a map of the entire world (a Rand McNally map with movement points and such printed over it), one of the first to cover modern warfare, and one of the first to allow for more than two players (although the emphasis is on the two-player game).

Expanded by:

Confrontation Expansion Kit
8149.name: Confrontation

8150.name: Confrontation Expansion Kit
8150.description:
This is a sheaf of paper containing these items:

The Second World War
This uses modified Confrontation rules for a 5-player WWII game.

Milopoliks
A multi-player 19th century military-political game. This uses the Confrontation maps and land counters but includes a new set of rules and six sheets of cards and counters to cut out (the latter are supposed to be glued to the back of the Confrontation counters).

Chief of State
A large multi-player game (up to 12 people, in theory) in which each player controls a nation's allocation of resources to industry, agricultural production, technology, etc., in an effort to improve its situation more than any other nation's (on a percentage basis). Conflict is heavily abstracted. This game uses the Confrontation maps, but has new rules, and doesn't use anything else except the included allocation forms. This game was designed by Scott Duncan.

The Gamescience Report
A newsletter, probably the first (only?) issue. It has some errata, clarifications, and optional rules for Confrontation.

Play-by-mail rules, plus the cold war and hot war order forms to use with them.

8151.name: Gekishin K.O.
8151.description:
A quick playing 2 player boxing game. There are over 100 different techniques/attacks that can be used. Each one is rated with stats on Damage, Motion (speed), Range, and Target Location. You win by knocking out the other player, which is accomplished by dealing 10 damage to any one area, such as the head, body, or arms. You try to guess where your opponent is attacking as well as roll a die to see if you defend against their attacks. It becomes a rock-paper-scissors type game of guessing.

The first in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring binder in bags and pouches.

8152.name: Dunk Jam
8152.description:
A 2 player basketball game. You choose three of the five available types of players to make up your team (each having a bonus for offensive movement, defensive movement, shooting, etc). You takes turns playing offense. The offensive player has 3 turns to play a card (1/turn) and get a shot off. The offensive player can move and pass the ball around, the defensive player move to block the offensive player, steal the ball, or block the shot. If the offensive player does not get a shot off by the end of the 3rd turn, its a turnover.

The closer you are to the basket, the easier the shot. There are two ways to resolve shots, either a simple roll of the twelve-sided die, with longer shots being tougher, or by a little dexterity shot where you flick a basketball up on a slightly angled board, and try to get it in the basket. The farther away you are on the main board, the further back you have to attempt the dexterity shot with.

The second in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring-binder in bags and pouches.

8153.name: Oval Trick
8153.description:
A racing game where each player starts with the same hand of cards The game is all about positioning and slipstreaming. When you move, you want to position yourself for a slipstream and also so that other players can't position themselves behind you for the same reason.

The third in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring-binder in bags and pouches.

8154.name: Fun Dive
8154.description:
A game where the object is to takes the best pictures of fish in 5 different locations before your air supply runs out.

Each turn, you deduct the air consumption for the turn (the lower you are, the more you lose), move the fish, move your guide piece, and your beginner piece. If you move your beginner piece onto one of the 5 fish pieces, you can take a photograph. There is a pile of cards for each of the 5 fish pieces. A good shot is worth more than a blurry shot. You can take more than one picture of the same fish over different turns, but only get to count the best shot for each of the 5 pieces for determining your score.

There is usually barely enough time to take pictures of all 5 pieces if you just take one shot of each, but sometimes there's not even that much time. It is usually easier to try to take a 2nd or 3rd picture of the same piece, but of course you then won't have time to get pictures of all 5 types of pieces.

The fourth in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring-binder in bags and pouches.

8155.name: Warumono
8155.description:
Each player has an attache case, but only one has the one with the valuables. If you are the mafia, then you grab the valuables, and try to flee from the other players. If you are a detective, you go after the player you think has the valuables and try to catch them. Players can purchase tickets to allow them to flee to certain areas. If you catch another player, you can switch attache cases with them.

The fifth in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring-binder in bags and pouches.

8156.name: Gouwan Strike
8156.description:
A baseball game that concentrates on the pitcher/batter match up. Each pitcher has 6 types of pitches they can throw. The pitcher selects a pitch card and places the card face down (the batter will only know if it's a 'slow' or 'fast' pitch), and places the ball on a square representing the location of the ball. The batter choosing to let the ball pass (if he thinks it'll be a ball), to bunt, or swing. To swing, he places the bat over 4 locations where he thinks the ball may end up. The pitcher then reveals the pitch, and rolls a die to see how many spaces and what direction the pitch moves to determine the final location of the pitch. Curve balls will move a few spaces inwards, a sinker downwards, and so on.

If the ball is hit, the batter rolls a die, and adds a bonus based on which of the 4 locations he covered the ball was thrown to (he may have a +4 to any pitch thrown to the upper right location, but no bonus for the other three squares, for example). For the most part, the higher the roll the better, and you get the results for the hit, such as double play, hit, double, and so on.

The sixth in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring binder in bags and pouches.

8157.name: Gateball?
8157.description:
Based off the Japanese sport of Gateball, which, while different, bears a few resemblances to Croquet.

Each team has 5 balls that they need to hit through 3 gates and then over the finish area. They get 1 point for each ball that gets past each gate, and 2 points for going over the finish line. These must be done in order. You can get a maximum of 5 points per ball (3 for the 3 gates, 2 for the finish).

There are 6 game turns, and in each turn, each ball can move (with different types of shots, such as power or technique). Each time you hit another ball, you get to shoot that ball off (whether its your own or an opponents), and then take an extra turn. You cannot have your current ball hit the same other ball multiple times, but if you hit different balls (or pass through gates) in succession, you can rack up many shots in a row.

The seventh in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring binder in bags and pouches.

8158.name: Inga
8158.description:
You select a party from amongst 50 characters. The object is to get 10 life-strength chips before the other players. You need a mix of characters, as certain human characters cannot go out at night, and vampire players cannot go out during the day.

The eighth in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring-binder in bags and pouches.

boardgamehonor.19625: 2002 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Japanese Game Nominee

8159.name: Regista
8159.description:
Watch as the game develops on the board using actual soccer strategies. Become both manager and play maker, taking control in your own unique way to lead your team to victory!
Comes with a multilingual rule book, including Japanese, English and German. Overcome the language and culture barrier, and battle it out against each other, one soccer theory against another!

http://www.grapac.co.jp/game/eng/eng_soccer/index.html

8160.description:
Rival mobs battle for control of the city. Take over the rackets, rake in the dough, and rub out the opposition. It's the American dream.

You'll start with a few gangsters and some cash. Recruit more crooks and take control of income-producing operations like bordellos, chop shops, and loan sharks. The police and the Feds are after you, but your biggest threats are your fellow mob bosses. Scheme, negotiate, back stab. You can share a victory, but it's much more satisfying to say "There can be only one Boss. And it's me."

Crime Lords is based on the Illuminati system. It's not a supplement, but a separate stand-alone game created by Steve Jackson.

Boxed game with 112 cards, rules, die-cut money and status counters, and dice. Illustrated by Dan Smith.
8160.name: Illuminati: Crime Lords

8161.description:
Panzerschreck Magazine #1 (Summer 1998)

The player (Russians) fights building to building in downtown Berlin, and must "fly the flag" over the Reichstag as quickly as possible. (solitaire, tactical level WW2 east front).

Components: 8.5" x 11" map, 72 counters, 22 Event cards, rules.

One Small Step Edition (2015) (Folio Series 8)
Starting on 12 January 1945, the Red Army breached the German front as a result of the Vistula–Oder Offensive and advanced westward as much as 40 kilometres (25 miles) a day through East Prussia, Lower Silesia, East Pomerania, and Upper Silesia, temporarily halting on a line 60 km (37 mi) east of Berlin along the Oder River. When the offensive resumed, two Soviet fronts (army groups) attacked Berlin from the east and south, while a third overran German forces positioned north of Berlin. The Battle in Berlin lasted from 20 April until the morning of 2 May.

Folio Contents:
1 16-Page Rules Book
16 Event Cards
1 half sheet of full-color, die-cut counters
1 17" x22" Map/Playing Surface
Charts and Tables
8161.name: Fall of Berlin

8162.name: Murder à la carte: A First Class Murder
8162.description:
Another in the Murder a la Carte line. Unlike other murder party publishers, this series relies on some lead-in scripted dialog and an audio tape to recap all that is learned (and add more information) during the night.

This particular episode takes place in the first-class compartments of a train in 1925. Snowbound travelers must determine who amongst them murdered a jockey on the way to the races at Oldmarket.

8163.name: CWARDS: The Ultimate Card & Word Game
8163.description: CWARDS is a card game and a word game mixed into one, combining the pastime of the former with the challenge of the latter. It is made up of 104 cards, divided into four series of the 26-letter alphabet so that every letter appears four times, once in each suit.

8164.name: Fast Golf
8164.description: A family card game for 2 or 4 players. Components include 54 stroke cards, 2 golf ball tokens, gameboard, and instructions.

8165.name: Himalaya Blackjack
8165.description:
Gear-up for blackjack - Himalayan style. Components include 6 reference cards, 15 camp cards, and a deck of 58 playing cards.

The cards are shuffled and stacked. One card is revealed to begin the discard pile. Players alternate taking turns by drawing the top card from the draw pile or drawing the top card from the discard pile. The goal is to get exactly 1000 in Meter cards. Having reached the goal, a player gets a Camp card. Some cards are Shortcuts which award a Camp card for having only 800 meters. There are hazard cards which hinder the unlucky player who draws one.

The winner is the first person to get four Camp cards and collect exactly 1000 meters more.

8166.description:
A boardgame based on a computer game (instead of the other way around) and designed by Klaus Teuber, Anno 1503 views the era of colonization strictly from the home country perspective. Two to four players send ships to explore islands scattered about a 5 x 12 square ocean (the more players, the more islands). The settlement of the new lands is, however, strictly abstract.

Each player's turn begins with the roll of one 6-sided die. A "6" is a random event (pirates, fire or good fortune - bad twice as often as lucky, and most likely to damage players who are doing well). On other results, each player gains a commodity from one of his five workshops. The player who rolled may then buy commodities from the bank, sell them to his colonists for gold (no trading among players), or use them in various combinations to recruit new colonists, promote existing ones, or build ships. After that, ships can sail for the unknown lands.

Each island bears on its hidden side an outpost, a treasure or a trade agreement. After being discovered, these items are brought back to the home country (and the ship is removed from play, requiring the player to build a new one in order to keep searching). Outposts increase the productivity of workshops. Treasure yields either gold or free colonist promotions. Trade agreements reduce the gold needed to buy commodities from the bank.

Besides being useful in these ways, outposts, gold and agreements are among the game's victory conditions. A player wins by being to first to attain three out of five objectives, namely, four outposts, 30 gold, three trade agreements, three colonists promoted to the top rank of "merchant" and the construction of four public buildings. The buildings (8 types, each bringing some advantage) cost nothing but don't become available until a player has recruited at least four colonists. After that, each new colonist adds a building (unless they've been preempted by other players; there aren't enough for everyone).

Overall, the game falls squarely into the "simultaneous solitaire" category. Except in the race for islands, the players scarcely interact at all. They do, however, have a great many choices to make in the course of play.
8166.name: Anno 1503

8167.name: Key-Cue
8167.description: Key-Cue is a word game that challenges each player to quickly identify the name of a subject, after listening to cues given for major syllables or groups of syllables that make up the subject name. Categories include persons, places, things, and events.

8168.name: Campus
8168.description:
Each player has a board covered in tiles with numbers on. The players take it in turns to roll two dice. The player who didn't roll the dice has to turn over tiles on his board with a value up to or equal to the dice roll. There are bonuses and penalties for some dice combinations, and for not spotting that you were entitled to a bonus. The game ends when one player has turned over all their tiles. The rules recommend that you play two games (one match), with the winner being the player with the lowest score (total numbers on tiles unturned)

Description from Triggery version

Triggery is a completely new game for all ages (from 8 upwards). It is played by ONE or TWO players, but it is just as exciting when played by 3 or 4.

To play Triggery you only have to be able to count up to 24. But make no mistake about it: to win you have to keep your eyes open, your thinking cap on ... and your wits about you!

The aim of the game? To turn face down all the tiles on your board as quickly - and in as few goes - as possible.

Is Triggery fun to play? It's a marvelous game. For one thing it has virtually limitless possibilities. For another, it's highly entertaining. But we are not going to spoil the fun by telling you why. Find out for yourself!

8169.name: Quits
8169.description: Quits is a game of classic simplicity which yet requires considerable powers of cunning and tactical positioning to win. It's a game in which you fight for territory by trying to place down your special Quits tokens into the right position at the right time. You're constantly jockeying for position, picking up points along the way, and trying at the same time to block off territory from your opponent.

25175.name: Die Rückkehr der Helden: Die Gralssuche

8170.description:
Players take the role of one fantasy hero traveling a hidden world, which is set up differently for every new game. Players gather mighty artifacts to solve their quests. The characters develop during the game, which brings some role-playing flair to the game. To help you feel comfortable with your character, you can even choose a gender by simply flipping the character card.

The game has been compared to Magic Realm and Talisman, with a complexity somewhere between the two.

Other games in the series:

Under the Shadow of the Dragon
Helden in der Unterwelt (Heroes in the Underworld)




Expanded by:

Under the Shadow of the Dragon
Die Rückkehr der Helden: Die Gralssuche (Return of the Heroes: Quest for the Grail)




Microbadges: (Buy One)
8170.name: Return of the Heroes

8171.name: Chug-A-Lug
8171.description:
OBJECT OF THE GAME:
CHUG-A-LUG is an exciting adult game of skill and fortune for two to six players. CHUG-A-LUG tests your drinking skill as well as your ability to cope with unusual and hilarious situations.

8172.description:
Coyote is a simple bluffing game in a western setting. Every player gets a card (bound on his forehead by a fabric tape) showing a number of "hidden" Indians or a special value. You don't know the value of your card, but you can see all the others. The object of the game is to guess how many Indians are shown on the cards, declaring an increasing number every turn. If you are caught over declaring, you lose.

Many special cards make every game turn a surprise, and don't forget you never know the card you are showing on your forehead.

The game has been reprinted by the italian company Oliphante in 2010.

Starting 2011, the french company Gigamic has got international rights and the game has been printed and distributed in a brand new edition.
8172.name: Coyote

8173.name: Battleship (first edition)
8173.description:
BATTLESHIP is a game of the maturing dreadnought. With the Washington Naval Conference and its resulting treaty limitations on ship numbers and tonnages, the battleship went completely over to 2nd generation designs, including all the major conversions, and then the final burst of 3rd generation dreadnoughts. Meantime, also as a result of the treaty, a now type of warship, the heavy cruiser, came to the fore and began a progress still unfinished in the modern missile cruiser. These events through 1945 are covered by BATTLESHIP. The game system was designed to reflect the concept of the Immune Zone, around which capital ship design revolved. This zone is roughly represented by the medium range defense value. But since when this value will come into effect is a result of the characteristics of the opposing player's guns, you must conduct your movements to, whenever possible, be in your immune zone while your opponent is being fired on at either long or short range. It is within these margins that damage can be done in safety. A hint: learn to use escorts. Properly handled they can shape an engagement early by threat of torpedo action."

Re-implemented by:

Battleship (second edition)

8174.description:
In Dschingis Bohn (Genghis Bean), Bohnaparte gets some serious competition. The Mongols overrun the Bohnreich and provide for new tactical challenges.

Hanno Girke's new Bohnanza expansion is suitable for 3-5 players. The Bohnanza base game is needed. By combining Dschingis Bohn with Bohnaparte up to 7 players can fight over the Bohnreich.

Dschingis Bohn is part of the Bohnanza family of games.

Expands

Bohnanza
8174.name: Dschingis Bohn

8175.description:
This is a set of 15 different cardboard discs depicting most of the bean types from the Bohnanza universe. These sheets were sold for 0.10 Euro each at Spiel 2003 in Essen. As of this writing, there are no published rules for the expansion, and the publishers are accepting suggestions.

The discs depict beans from the German base game and revised expansion set (including an Ackerbohne), as well as the three beans unique to Al Cabohne. Absentees include the two beans introduced in La Isla Bohnitâ (Wachsbohne and Mokkabohne) and the Cognacbohne from Amigo's revised edition of High Bohn.

The missing Wachsbohne may be especially puzzling to owners of the Rio Grande Games base set: the German editions of the Bohnanza expansion set do not have 22 Wachsbohnen, but rather 22 Weinbrandbohnen. This means no Wax Bean disc for you, so you'll probably want to use the staggering "brandy bean" disc as a proxy.

The Bohnanza counters are part of the Bohnanza family of games.
8175.name: Bohnanza Counters

8176.name: UNO: X-Men
8176.description:
Standard Uno-themed card game.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The "Mutate" card -- a wild card that allows you to discard all but one card and draw again to make up a new hand, or force an opponent to do so instead.

8177.description:
Standard Uno-themed card game.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: "Spider Sense" card which is both a wild card and allows you to view an opponents hand.
8177.name: UNO: Spider-Man

8178.description: This game from JKLM involves swapping tiles in order to match patterns and stopping your opponent from doing the same. This plays as a 2 or 3 player game.
8178.name: Constellation

boardgamehonor.21039: 2004 Spiel der Spiele Hit für Familien Recommended

8179.description:
From the directions:

Welcome to Yellowstone Park, the home of many wild animals. Impressive geysers spray their hot fountains into the blue sky. The players go on a trip through the park, which is shown on the game board. Each player has a hand of animal cards with different colors and numbers. During the game the players try to put their cards down as skillfully as possible on the game board to avoid penalty points.
8179.name: Yellowstone Park

8180.description:
40 cards of flowers (5 colors, 1-8 flowers on each card) are placed in a 5x8 grid. Both players collect flower cards with their pawn by moving across the grid following two rules: 1) pawns may never move backwards, but may turn 90 degrees before movement; 2) each collected card has to show fewer flowers than the last collected card of that color. Scoring rewards big collections of one color.

Online Play


http://www.mastermoves.eu/ (turn-based)
http://www.onlinebrettspiele.de/ (AI)
8180.name: Floriado

8181.name: Adam Games Football
8181.description:
Adam Games Football is a statistical replay game. The charts that are included create by dice roll a replay of past seasons. The game is simple to play. You call a running play or passing play and then roll the dice. There are charts for individual teams and on those charts are listings of who throws the pass or makes the run and then influenced by the defensive rating of the opposition another roll determines how large the gain is on a run or whether or not the pass is complete. There are the possibilities for fumbles and penalties and sacks.

The publisher used to have many years of pro and college teams available, but the website is now defunct.

8182.name: Crown of the Emperor
8182.description:
Players construct a deck of military might, characters, and industries, vying for the emperor's seat in the year 2909. Building your own empire Players start with 10 Prestige points, and win by either raising their own Prestige to 40, or lowering their opponent's prestige to 0.

Five pre-constructed decks are offered, each representing a different "faction" with a special way of gaining bonus prestige.

8183.name: Fence & Fenceability
8183.description: You are trying to fence counterfeit art. On your turn you are the counterfeiter and the rest of the players are the fences trying to sell your work and earn money. You will sometimes bluff to be able to sell the art. When the game ends the winner is the one with most money on hand.

8184.description:
The only thing worse than acting at Deadwood Studios, debasing yourself for a tiny paycheck by playing such memorable roles as "Man on Fire", is having to go somewhere else to do it. If the gig at Deadwood Studios wasn't bad enough, now you're working "on location"

Deadwood: On Location is a set of new boards for the Deadwood game, representing six different sets and the bus stops that connect them. You'll need the rules from Deadwood to play, as well as those cards. On Location is also compatible with the four "Another Day, Another Dollar" card expansions.
8184.name: Deadwood: On Location

8185.name: Ruhe in Frieden
8185.description: Every player has got 5 relatives that are on the brink of dying. The trouble is that there are only 5 graves to bury them in and they all want to be buried in the same cemetery. So you have to speed up your relatives destiny by bribing the doctor to give them placebo medicine while trying to help the doctor keep other players relatives alive.

8186.name: Ambulance Chase
8186.description: A small Cheapass style envelope game that requires some cutting of counters before play can start. The object of the game is to pick up patients with your ambulance and deliver them safe to the nearest hospital. You earn money for this and the first to accumulate $20 wins the game. The trouble comes when you start to move to fast and can't avoid other players' ambulances, other vehicles and buildings. Ramming something will happen a lot.

8187.name: The Power of Quasar
8187.description:
A bizarre almost-self-published game (Quasar Ent. is based in Edmonton, Ab) uses a huge roulette-like contraption as part of its board. The pieces are things that came from hardware supply stores (those little plastic caps for twisting wires together make nifty rocketships, eh?), including the magnets one must mount into the board. The roulette I mentioned is spun now and then during the game, and the magnets and iron bars ensure it "clicks" into proper alignment every time.

Basically a two-player game, it can be played by teams of two or three. There are nine "winning levels" of varying point value: the Weeble (conquer three star bases of different colours), the Skunk (conquer the Time Zone, e.g. 8 blue planets plus a Quasar Shield), the Sweep (conquer all six Star Bases without Weebling first), the Shield (possessing both Quasar Shields), the Shaft (Weeble and Shield), the Level (Skunk and Shield), the Fase (Sweep and Shield), the Scoop (Weeble, Shield and Skunk) and the Quase (Sweep, Shield and Skunk). And then it gets complicated...

The game is just plain weird, with a distant whiff of Cosmic Encounter to it.

8188.description:
This is a fast Soccer-Cardgame based on the German children's book and movie DIE WILDEN FUßBALLKERLE.
The cartoon-like cards show teenagers in street clothes ready to play soccer. You try to make as much goals as possible by dueling one of your cards with one of the opponent's card. Action cards and special abilities further alter the outcome of each Duel.
8188.name: Die wilden Fußballkerle

8189.name: Cargo Wars
8189.description:
First published in 1990, the game has since been reprinted in a more reasonably-sized box. Aggressively marketed, it is still in print.

«Do you like Monopoly? Do you like Risk? Then you'll love Cargo Wars!»
«Enter the world of international shipping and piracy on the high seas! Players compete as each attempts to corner global shipping [...] Pirate contracts abound as players smuggle contraband in an attempt to increase cash flow.»

The game owes a lot to Rail Baron and is also a distant relative of Pirate and Traveler. The shipping lanes are progressively bought out as one completes pick-up-and-deliver contracts, with the added twist that some contracts (more lucrative) are "illegal" --other players may attempt to run you down for a bounty. Like in Rail Baron, you must get back to your "home city" to win --again with other players attempting to run you down as you do so.

8190.description:
In Shangri-La, the mysterious and isolated utopia nestled high in the mountains, a strange struggle for dominance has begun. Once peaceful and neighborly, the Masters of the competing mountain-folk train their students and send them out across bridges to control neighboring villages. To take control of a village, the students must come together in uncomfortable alliances, regardless of their tribal origin. Eventually students become Masters themselves, train new students and expand to other villages.

There is one thing each student must keep in mind as they travel from village to village -- the mystical powers of Shangri-La mysteriously cause the bridges to collapse, separating villages forever. One crucial question will decide the winner: who will control the most Masters of Shangri-La?

Players take on the roles of leaders of a specific tribe. There is a battle raging over the empty villages of the land and players must quickly fill those villages with their tribal leaders. As players migrate tribal leaders from one village to the next, they must not become too weak or they risk losing leaders to opposing tribes. The ultimate object of the game is to have the most leaders on the board at the end of the game.
It is an abstract game with many options and tense until the end.

2004 Mensa Select

Thematically, players are adding masters and students, and trying to have the students migrate to nearby villages to become masters. Functionally, this is essentially a military game. Players either spend their turn reinforcing a village (adding more tokens there) or invading a neighboring village (expanding influence if you have more total tokens than the victim). The unique twist is that, after each invasion, the connecting bridge is removed. So over the course of the game, attack options become more and more limited, until the game naturally comes to a conclusion.
8190.name: The Bridges of Shangri-La

8191.description:
This is a stand-alone follow-up game to Gastérospeed or Snail's Pace introducing six new tracks and some new cards. It is still the same snail racing game where you, by playing speed cards, compete to be the first across the finish line.
The boards are progressively more dangerous, and require some good thinking at the end of the series, although luck does have a major role in the game.
Still, it is a fast game with a lot of humor added. So it is excellent to play when you have only a short time for a game, and do not want to spend the evening explaining rules to people.

Re-implements:

Gastérospeed
8191.name: Snail Race
